segment.source: Boot to VHD (Native Boot): Add a Virtual Hard Disk to the Boot Menu
segment.target: Boot to VHD (Native Boot): Add a Virtual Hard Disk to the Boot Menu

segment.source: Boot to VHD (Native Boot): Add a Virtual Hard Disk to the Boot Menu
segment.target: Boot to VHD (Native Boot): Add a Virtual Hard Disk to the Boot Menu

segment.source: Boot to VHD (Native Boot): Add a Virtual Hard Disk to the Boot Menu
segment.target: Boot to VHD (Native Boot): Add a Virtual Hard Disk to the Boot Menu

segment.source: Native Boot allows you to create a virtual hard disk (VHD), install Windows to it, and then boot it up, either on your PC side-by-side with your existing installation, or on a new device.
segment.target: Native Boot allows you to create a virtual hard disk (VHD), install Windows to it, and then boot it up, either on your PC side-by-side with your existing installation, or on a new device.

segment.source: A native-boot VHD can be used as the running operating system on designated hardware without any other parent operating system.
segment.target: A native-boot VHD can be used as the running operating system on designated hardware without any other parent operating system.

segment.source: This differs from a scenario where a VHD is connected to a virtual machine on a computer that has a parent operating system.
segment.target: This differs from a scenario where a VHD is connected to a virtual machine on a computer that has a parent operating system.

segment.source: VHDs can be applied to PCs or devices that have no other installations of Windows, without a virtual machine or hypervisor.
segment.target: VHDs can be applied to PCs or devices that have no other installations of Windows, without a virtual machine or hypervisor.

segment.source: (A hypervisor is a layer of software under the operating system that runs virtual computers.) This enables greater flexibility in workload distribution because a single set of tools can be used to manage images for virtual machines and designated hardware.
segment.target: (A hypervisor is a layer of software under the operating system that runs virtual computers.) This enables greater flexibility in workload distribution because a single set of tools can be used to manage images for virtual machines and designated hardware.

segment.source: You can also deploy the VHD to a PC that already has Windows installed on it, and use a boot menu to select between the existing version of Windows, or the version on the VHD.
segment.target: You can also deploy the VHD to a PC that already has Windows installed on it, and use a boot menu to select between the existing version of Windows, or the version on the VHD.

segment.source: To learn more about using VHDs in an enterprise environment, see Understanding Virtual Hard Disks with Native Boot.
segment.target: To learn more about using VHDs in an enterprise environment, see Understanding Virtual Hard Disks with Native Boot.

segment.source: Prerequisites
segment.target: Prerequisites

segment.source: A technician PC with the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (Windows ADK) tools installed on it.
segment.target: A technician PC with the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (Windows ADK) tools installed on it.

segment.source: A generalized Windows image (.WIM file).
segment.target: A generalized Windows image (.WIM file).

segment.source: To learn more, see Sysprep (Generalize) a Windows installation.
segment.target: To learn more, see Sysprep (Generalize) a Windows installation.

segment.source: A bootable Windows PE drive.
segment.target: A bootable Windows PE drive.

segment.source: To learn more, see WinPE: Create USB Bootable drive.
segment.target: To learn more, see WinPE: Create USB Bootable drive.

segment.source: A destination PC or device on which to install the VHD.
segment.target: A destination PC or device on which to install the VHD.

segment.source: This device requires 30 gigabytes (GB) or more of free disk space.
segment.target: This device requires 30 gigabytes (GB) or more of free disk space.

segment.source: You can install the VHD to a device already running other operating system installations, or as the only operating system on a device.
segment.target: You can install the VHD to a device already running other operating system installations, or as the only operating system on a device.

segment.source: Step 1: Create a VHD from diskpart
segment.target: Step 1: Create a VHD from diskpart

segment.source: On the technician PC, open Diskpart.
segment.target: On the technician PC, open Diskpart.

segment.source: Create and prepare a new VHD.
segment.target: Create and prepare a new VHD.

segment.source: In this example, we create a 25 GB fixed-type VHD.
segment.target: In this example, we create a 25 GB fixed-type VHD.

segment.source: Attach the VHD.
segment.target: Attach the VHD.

segment.source: This adds the VHD as a disk to the storage controller on the host.
segment.target: This adds the VHD as a disk to the storage controller on the host.

segment.source: Create a partition for the Windows files, format it, and assign it a drive letter.
segment.target: Create a partition for the Windows files, format it, and assign it a drive letter.

segment.source: This drive letter will appear in File Explorer.
segment.target: This drive letter will appear in File Explorer.

segment.source: Exit Diskpart
segment.target: Exit Diskpart

segment.source: Step 2: Apply a Windows image to the VHD
segment.target: Step 2: Apply a Windows image to the VHD

segment.source: Apply a generalized Windows image to the primary partition of the VHD.
segment.target: Apply a generalized Windows image to the primary partition of the VHD.

segment.source: Step 3: Detach the VHD, copy it to a new device, and attach it (optional)
segment.target: Step 3: Detach the VHD, copy it to a new device, and attach it (optional)

segment.source: You can deploy the VHD to a device that already has a copy of Windows installed on it, or you can clean and prepare the drive to just use the VHD.
segment.target: You can deploy the VHD to a device that already has a copy of Windows installed on it, or you can clean and prepare the drive to just use the VHD.

segment.source: Detach the VHD and save it to a network share or storage drive
segment.target: Detach the VHD and save it to a network share or storage drive

segment.source: Detach the virtual disk.
segment.target: Detach the virtual disk.

segment.source: Copy the VHD to a network share or removable storage drive.
segment.target: Copy the VHD to a network share or removable storage drive.

segment.source: Clean and prepare a new device for native boot
segment.target: Clean and prepare a new device for native boot

segment.source: Boot the destination device to Windows Preinstallation Environment (WinPE).
segment.target: Boot the destination device to Windows Preinstallation Environment (WinPE).

segment.source: Clean and prepare the drive.
segment.target: Clean and prepare the drive.

segment.source: Create a system partition (S), and a main partition (M) where the VHD will be stored.
segment.target: Create a system partition (S), and a main partition (M) where the VHD will be stored.

segment.source: BIOS:
segment.target: BIOS:

segment.source: UEFI:
segment.target: UEFI:

segment.source: Connect to a network drive or storage location, and note the drive letter.
segment.target: Connect to a network drive or storage location, and note the drive letter.

segment.source: Copy the VHD to the main partition.
segment.target: Copy the VHD to the main partition.

segment.source: Attach the VHD
segment.target: Attach the VHD

segment.source: Attach the VHD.
segment.target: Attach the VHD.

segment.source: Identify the volume letter.
segment.target: Identify the volume letter.

segment.source: (Optional: Change it to another letter that makes more sense, for example V, and leave the diskpart command line open for the next step).
segment.target: (Optional: Change it to another letter that makes more sense, for example V, and leave the diskpart command line open for the next step).

segment.source: Step 4: Add a boot entry
segment.target: Step 4: Add a boot entry

segment.source: Open Diskpart (if necessary) and identify the drive letters of the VHD and the system partition, for example, V and S.
segment.target: Open Diskpart (if necessary) and identify the drive letters of the VHD and the system partition, for example, V and S.

segment.source: Add a boot entry to the device.
segment.target: Add a boot entry to the device.

segment.source: You can add multiple VHD files using this method.
segment.target: You can add multiple VHD files using this method.

segment.source: BIOS:
segment.target: BIOS:

segment.source: UEFI:
segment.target: UEFI:

segment.source: Remove the Windows PE USB key.
segment.target: Remove the Windows PE USB key.

segment.source: Restart the device.
segment.target: Restart the device.

segment.source: If there's only one boot entry, the device immediately boots to Windows.
segment.target: If there's only one boot entry, the device immediately boots to Windows.

segment.source: If there's more than one boot entry, you'll see a boot menu where you can choose between the available versions of Windows on the device.
segment.target: If there's more than one boot entry, you'll see a boot menu where you can choose between the available versions of Windows on the device.
